Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Social Dynamics of Information in Virtual Spaces

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to model the effect of community structure on information diffusion through the analysis of online interactions. As our lives are increasingly conducted in the digital domain, these online activities represent a growing proportion of our interactions - from the way we acquire and share information, to the way we communicate, socialize, and organize. Such activities leave digital traces, ranging from citation patterns among millions of blogs to avatar interactions in online virtual worlds such as Second Life.

Empirical studies of these traces will address the following information diffusion and social network phenomena on an unprecedented scale and with great accuracy: 1) the interplay between social network structure, community affiliation and interaction; 2) the effect of social network structure and community boundaries on information diffusion and change; 3) the range of influence of individuals, related to the structure of their social network and community affiliation; 4) the dynamics of opinion formation in networks of overlapping communities.

The topic of information diffusion, having both theoretical and practical significance, has received sustained attention across several scientific disciplines for some time. However, past empirical studies have lacked the size and accuracy needed to differentiate between different theoretical models. To address this problem, this project will assemble three very large scale, high resolution network data sources: one encompassing the interactions of millions of users of the online virtual world Second Life, the second comprising millions of blogs, and the third mapping exact traces with a novel information and opinion sharing application that will be developed. Together, these three contexts will serve as a testbed for modeling the dynamics of information diffusion. Beyond testing existing models, this project will incorporate network community boundaries and overlap into new descriptive and predictive models of information diffusion and opinion formation.

Understanding how information diffuses and how opinions are formed in today's highly connected and community-focused online environments has important implications not just for public policy and marketing, but also for the dissemination of innovations. Knowing how to traverse community boundaries, or conversely, to target different communities separately, can also facilitate the spread and adoption of educational and community outreach efforts, including those initiated by several educational institutions in Second Life. The research will directly feed into network and data analysis courses taught by the principal investigator as part of two new social computing and information retrieval Masters of Information Science specializations. It will add to a collection of online data sets, analysis tools, and tutorials already shared by the principal investigator for educational and research purposes. Some of the online tutorials will be adapted as interactive exhibits in Second Life. To educate an even younger audience, one or more Discovery Carts on the topic of social networks will be developed in collaboration with the Ann Arbor Hands-on Museum, which will become part of the museum's outreach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Award #0746646

CAREER: Social Dynamics of Information in Virtual Spaces

PI: Lada Adamic

 

  1. 1.     Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts

Our lives are increasingly conducted in the digital domain. These online activities represent a growing proportion of our interactions – from the way we acquire and share information, to the way we work, socialize, and communicate.  Such activities leave digital traces, ranging from citation patterns among millions of blogs, to Twitter tweets written and retweeted, to avatar interactions in online virtual worlds, such as Second Life. The research objective of this project was to model the effect of community structure on information diffusion through the analysis of online interactions in networks such as Facebook, Twitter, and Second Life.

  1. Intellectual merit

In addition to exploring why different networks have different structures, the project also looked at the nature of the information itself: whether it remains constant or mutates and whether it is true or false. Findings indicate that given the presence of false information, fact-checking resources can be distributed to stem the spread of misinformation. By studying diverse online topics ranging from online game dynamics to interactions between sellers in online virtual worlds to the role of culture in social media, the research demonstrated that information diffusion can be tracked and predicted in social networks using their temporal, structural and content features. Likewise, information flow paths, changes in information content, as well as how information veracity affects the spread can be measured. Interestingly, truth spreads at about the same rate as fiction, though once identified as either true or false, the false information is more likely to be removed.

  1. Broader impacts:

This research demonstrated a means of understanding how information diffuses and how opinions are formed in today’s highly connected and community-focused online environments. It has important implications for public policy and marketing, as well as the diffusion of innovations. It also indicates how either traversing community boundaries, or conversely, targeting different communities separately, can also facilitate the spread and adoption of information. This could be applied to educational and community outreach efforts. Potentially, findings from this research could be applied in diverse domains, such as medicine (spread of contagion in hospitals) and journalism (spread of rumors and misinformation).

  1. Other products that have resulted from the award also are to be listed. Examples of other products include collections, data sets, software, as well as educational materials.

In addition to publications, this project featured other products. The principal investigator’s social networks analysis course, Networks: Theory and Application, was made available through the University of Michigan's Open.Michigan Open Educational Resources (see http://open.umich.edu/education/si/si508/fall2008). A Coursera course "Social Network Analysis" was developed. Over 4,000 completed the course and earned a certificate over the 3 iterations it was offered: Fall 2012, Spring 2013 and Fall 2013. The course incorporated network theory, hands-on analysis of data sets, and agent based modeling (see https://www.coursera.org/course/sna).
